title: Men publicly caned after being accused of gambling in Indonesia
text:
A man accused of gambling receives a public caning punishment in Banda Aceh (Picture: EPA)

Shariah police in Indonesia publicly whipped two man charged with gambling today.

The men, dressed in white robes, were viewed by crowds being hit with a cane.

They were forced to stand with hands clasped as people took photos on cameras and mobile phones.

It happened in Banda Aceh, a province in northern Sumatra which is the only part of Indonesia where shariah law is implemented.

Despite international condemnation, public flogging is a common punishment for a range of offences in the conservative region, including gambling, drinking alcohol, and having gay or pre-marital sex.

A total of 34 countries around the world, including Singapore, Saudia Arabia, Pakistan and Nigeria, still use forms of judicial corporal punishments including caning and birching.

Public flogging is a common punishment for a range of offences in the conservative region on Sumatra island (Picture: Getty)

A member of the Sharia police waits before today’s public caning (Picture: Getty)

Aceh is the only province in Indonesia that implements Sharia law (Picture: EPA)

One of the men being whipped (Picture: Getty)

The man is escorted on a stage to receive a public caning punishment (Picture: EPA)

In August this year, a woman was seen breaking down in agony after being whipped 100 times for having sex before marriage.

At one stage, the woman begs for the masked Sharia officer to stop beating her with a rattan cane.

The whipping stopped briefly but resumed after a doctor checked on the woman.

Her boyfriend, also aged 22, received 100 strikes after they were caught having pre-marital sex.

Rights groups have slammed public caning as cruel, and Indonesia’s President Joko Widodo has called for it to end, but the practice has support among Aceh’s population.

Conservative Aceh province was granted special autonomy to implement shariah law in 2001 to end a separatist insurgency.
